thread.title: Markets diary

title: Markets diary
text:
Burnt fingers keep merger arbs at bay 
Among the most closely watched companies will be IBM , which has been hard at work trying to boost its cloud computing business in recent quarters. 
Big Blue has struggled as consumers have increasingly begun utilising smartphones and tablets, and many companies have started to employ centralised data centres instead of traditional servers to conduct business. 
Several other blue-chips are on tap, including industrial giant United Technologies , heavy machinery maker Caterpillar , credit card company American Express , aerospace behemoth Boeing , and software maker Microsoft . 
Investors will also see the latest results from fast-food bellwether McDonald’s , and Chipotle Mexican Group, the poplar fast casual restaurant. 
Earnings from Yahoo will also likely garner attention as investors await any updates on its plans to spin off its stake in Alibaba . Chinese third-quarter GDP 
Away from earnings, the week starts on Sunday evening (New York time) with quarterly gross domestic product data from China. 
The world’s second-biggest economy is forecast to have expanded at the slowest pace since 2009 in the third quarter. US housing 
American economic reports will focus on the housing sector. Data Tuesday should provide insight on how the market for newly-built homes is faring, while a release on sales of previously-owned homes is due out on Thursday. European Central Bank meeting 
Also on Thursday is a policy decision from the European Central Bank. 
While analysts expect the ECB to hold rates steady, expectations that the central bank may accelerate asset purchases in light of very weak inflation across the currency bloc have hardened. Chinese president in the UK 
Chinese President Xi Jinping will also make a five-day trip to the UK. The subjects of human rights and closer economic co-operation may come up. Clinton on Benghazi 
In US political news, Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton is expected to testify before a House committee over the 2012 attack at an American consulate in Benghazi, Libya. Mrs Clinton was secretary of state at the time. Related Topics
